title: R46117
content: The TEACH Grant program provides grants to students pursuing teaching careers. Recipients must teach in high-need fields for at least four years or repay the grant as a loan. Over 300,000 grants totaling nearly $938 million have been disbursed since 2008. Challenges in administering the program include loan conversions for recipients who fail to submit required paperwork. The TEACH Grant program faces challenges with grant-to-loan conversions due to administrative issues. Two-thirds of recipients are expected to have their grants converted to loans, raising concerns about the program's effectiveness. Congressional attention may focus on program design issues, including identifying qualified teachers, grant benefit size, finding teaching placements, teacher preparation program quality, and the definition of a "highly qualified teacher." Implementation challenges like certification of teaching service and the lack of an appeals process also need to be addressed. The TEACH Grant program was authorized in 2007 under the College Cost Reduction and Access Act. It aims to address the shortage of qualified teachers in public schools. Challenges include grant-to-loan conversions, program design issues, and implementation challenges like certification of teaching service and the absence of an appeals process. Lawmakers may need to consider proposed changes and issues related to the program in the 116th Congress. The TEACH Grant program was authorized in 2007 to address the shortage of qualified teachers in low-income schools by attracting high-achieving individuals into the teaching profession through financial incentives to help subsidize the cost of college. This was in response to concerns about retirements, teacher quality standards, and retention issues in low-income schools. The TEACH Grant program aims to attract high-quality individuals to teaching by providing financial assistance upfront to influence career paths. It targets schools and subjects that struggle to retain staff, particularly in low-income areas. Critics argue that the program is poorly targeted and places a financial burden on taxpayers, lacking focus on increasing access to higher education for students in need. The TEACH Grant program underwent changes under the Higher Education Opportunity Act, including the development of a plain-language disclosure form for recipients. Recipients in fields no longer designated as "high need" could still fulfill their service requirement by teaching in that field. Extenuating circumstances could waive all or part of the service requirement. The TEACH Grant program, authorized under the Higher Education Opportunity Act, required ED to report to Congress every two years on recipients and schools served. Before TEACH Grants, the Paul Douglas Teacher Scholarships program provided $5,000 per year to top 10% high school graduates for teaching service. The TEACH Grant program was administered as a formula grant to states, which selected scholarship recipients and monitored service requirements. It was repealed in 1998 due to being duplicative and costly to administer. Another similar program is the NSF's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, providing scholarships to STEM majors in exchange for teaching service. TEACH Grants can be awarded for multiple programs of study, with four years of teaching service required for each program. Eligibility for disbursing TEACH Grants requires meeting general Title IV institutional eligibility requirements. The Higher Education Act (HEA) requires institutions of higher education (IHEs) to meet specific eligibility requirements for teacher preparation programs. These requirements include providing high-quality teacher preparation, financial responsibility, pedagogical coursework, clinical experience, and supervision and support services for teachers. To be eligible for TEACH Grants, an IHE must meet financial responsibility standards, offer accredited teacher preparation programs, and provide a minimum of 10 weeks of full-time clinical experience. The TEACH Grant-eligible IHE must offer pedagogical coursework, supervision, and support services to teachers. It should provide a two-year program of study acceptable for full credit towards a bachelor's teacher preparation degree or a bachelor's degree in a high-need field. Additionally, it must offer a bachelor's degree or post-baccalaureate program to prepare students to teach in a high-need field. A post-baccalaureate program offered by an IHE that also offers a bachelor's degree in education is not TEACH Grant-eligible. TEACH Grant-eligible programs prepare individuals to teach in high-need fields and lead to a bachelor's or Master's degree.
